headline: Indian Style Basmati Rice
description: This savory Indian rice recipe gets its signature flavor from whole spices and fried onions. Serve with your favorite Indian curry or dal.

name: Indian Style Basmati Rice

recipeInstructions.text: Place rice into a bowl with enough water to cover. Set aside to soak for 20 minutes.

Meanwhile, in the last 10 minutes of soaking, heat oil in a large pot or saucepan over medium heat. Add cinnamon stick, cardamom pods, and cloves, then stir in cumin seed. Cook and stir until fragrant and toasted, about a minute, then add onion to the pot. Saute onion until the color is a rich golden brown, about 10 minutes.
Drain water from rice, and stir into the pot. Cook and stir rice until lightly toasted, about 3 minutes. Add water and salt, and bring to a boil. Cover and reduce heat to low.
Simmer for about 15 minutes, or until all the water has been absorbed. Let stand for 5 minutes, then fluff with a fork before serving.

review.reviewBody: I have made this recipe 3 times and followed instructions to a tee. I have several co workers from India and they said it reminded them of being back in India..lol.. one coworker said it was better rice than his wife cooks at home . I love this recipe and so do my friends/coworkers from India . Legit Recipe !
Follow the directions to a tee. Came out great.
Yum! Added a little turmeric for color.

Easy and flavorful. Didnâ€™t have cardamom pods so used powdered with a light hand. Also, based on reviews, increased the cloves. Soaking and toasting the rice made for beautifully separate firm grains of rice.

I absolutely love this recipe for making my rice & use it each time I make a curry. Iâ€™ve shared this recipe with family & friends too. Iâ€™ve tweaked it a little & add 4 or 5 cloves & about 6 or so green cardamom pods, then once cooked I remove the pods, scrape out the seeds & stir them in â€¦ delicious! ðŸ˜‹ â€¦ I love a cardamom seed bursting in your teeth, best spice flavour EVER,

I thought I didnâ€™t have cardamom (turns out I did), so I used nutmeg (recommended on the internet). I also used brown basmati rice so had to cook it longer. Not sure if Iâ€™ll make again??

I FELL IN LOVE WITH THE RECIPE I LOVE IT AND MY FAMILY DID AS WELL

I made it yesterday night to accompany a chicken tikka masala. Very flavourful and fragrant. I substituted powederd cinnamon as I was out of sticks (1 tsp) and, if anything, I would increase a bit more spices next time (I am not. aspicy person: I am European and we are notorious for blend flavor profiles...). I was surprise about people commenting on too much cumin: is suspect they mistook seed for powder.

This authentic Indian style rice is spot on. All the way from the fragrance to the flavor, your taste buds will jump! This is my go to recipe for Indian style rice. Tastes EXACTLY like you'd get at an Indian restaurant. As far as changes, I left out the onion as I believe onion has no place in rice, however I do use thinly sliced onion in my Tikka Masala sauce and thinly sliced red onion in my Byrani. If you leave out the onion, make sure you saute the pods, cloves, cinnamon stick and cumin seeds for a few minutes in the hot oil to open up those flavors and fragrance. Also, don't forget to rinse and soak the rice, it's extremely important. Equally as important as using Basmatti rice. One other change I made is that I used 1 less clove. Not a huge fan of clove unless the flavor is buried amongst other flavors! Enjoy!!
What a great recipe. Absolutely love this. So easy to make. Great addition to any meal. Thanks.

I have to say, this recipe never fails. My rice is always super delicious, reminds me exactly of the wonderful Indian restaurants in my area. 
I do rinse the rice several times to ensure maximum fluffiness.

Wow, this was GREAT! Just like an Indian restaurant we used to frequent. I did use ground spices instead of whole (another reviewer gave the equivalents) I actually made it in my Instant pot- fast easy and delicious
was very very good

I never dreamed it was possible to make rice this delicious at home! Next time I will take the advice of another reviewer and skip the soaking step to see how that effects the texture, but it was great as it was and my whole house still smells amazing hours later. Thank you for this fantastic recipe!
This recipe turned out perfect! I served it with Sri Lankan curry and my family loved it.

I love this rice! I doubled the recipe except for the oil. I stuck with 2 tbsp. I added black mustard seed, and bay leaf to the mix of spices. A small pinch of celtic salt. Allowing the spices to bloom in the saute really releases their flavor. Crushing the green cardamom pods a bit before cooking lets this fabulous flavor be more predominant. I really like the tip to continue to steam the rice for 10 minutes with the lid still on. We love this rice!
Great recipe! Full of flavor!

I used all of the measurements with no subs (maybe extra oil when toasting to keep the rice from sticking). After the toasting step, I finished in the rice cooker. I put enough water to cover the rice without measuring. I love it! I wasnâ€™t sure if it would have flavor, but it does. I plan to make more this week.
Great recipe... definitely Indian style. Next time I might try a little less cumin seed.
this is really tasty but I would up the cloves and other spice except the cinnamon For an extra kick you can add a teaspoon of black mustard seed with the other spices.
Yummy and fragrant., my family thought it was great with my Costco Chicken Tikki Masala
Great flavor. I will do this again, but add more of the spices.
I loved it.
This was really good. Iâ€™m usually not a fan of basmati rice but this was perfect, flavorful and delicious.
My children LOVE Indian food and I enjoy finding a recipe they like. This one was perfect and went very well with other dishes we have as staple mains. They enjoyed every bite!

I wanted to make all of my husband's favorite Indian foods to keep his spirits up during the isolation of the pandemic. I had never made naan before and I feel like I can do better, BUT it tasted wonderful. My husband was very happy.

I thought this was pretty good, but it turns out my hubby prefers his rice "plain" - not sure what's up with that, but I thought this was a good recipe with great seasonings and it felt fancy to serve it with my favorite Indian dish. Would definitely make it again.
It was delicious!! My family gobbled it up. We put Dal Tarka over the rice and it was nearly as good as the food I got in Bangalore, India!
This turned out SO good! This was my first time ever trying to make Indian food and I can say I am not at all disappointed with the results!
This recipe is exceptional. Admittedly I did not have everything on hand, so I subbed a bit of cumin for the cumin seed and some Garam Marsala for the cardamom.

I added ground turkey and green peas to make it a meal then ate with naan and Tzatziki Sauce and that made it perfection.
It was pretty good. I learned to cook Indian food in London by Indian friends. This is pretty close to how I learned to make it.

I've cooked this probably 10-15 times since finding this recipe. So far, it's my go-to Indian rice recipe. I screwed up rice for a long time before I finally found this recipe.

 I add a couple cloves of minced garlic with the cumin seed, the flavor is not remarkably different, but great either way. I use way more oil than is called for. I don't measure it, I pour a couple tablespoons before adding spices, then a little more with the onions if they don't seem to be wet and slippery looking. I probably use closer to 4 Tablespoons total (I am NOT a low-fat chef) I cook everything in a big stainless pot with a super-thick (like 1") base. The oil keeps anything from sticking to the pot, and keeps the grains separate when done. When toasting the rice before adding the water, I cook and stir until I can hear that the water clinging to the rice has basically cooked off.

As soon as it reaches a boil, I set the timer for 15 min, turn the heat as far down as it goes, and cover. When the timer goes off, I immediately invert into a big mixing bowl and fluff then let stand. I found that letting it stand in the pot just overcooks the bottom, probably because of my heavy base.

Fried in a wok the following day, this rice is even better which is saying a lot. Spectacular. Never found anyone that didn't love it. I am not ethnically Indian however.

I did this with jasmine rice and the flavor is good, but it's super sticky. Basmati is far better.
First time making this, and could not have been happier. We were initially hesitant to add the onion, but so glad we did. This was 'Print and save' worthy...as we will definitely be making it often.

We used basmati brown rice and doubled the recipe. I like my foods bold in flavor so I added more cloves and cardamom. I also added diced bits of dried apricot and whole golden raisins. I used a sweet onion. (In retrospect I would have added one more cinnamon stick. We loved the finished dish and we would have enjoyed the original more mild version too. the recipe, I had to add a half hour to the cooking time. My sister absolutely loved it and took home the leftovers.
Super easy, and really tasty. I did need to add more salt, and I'm usually sensitive to overly-salty things, but no biggie.
Worth the effort of sautÃ©ing the onion and spices.

This is delicious! I used brown basmatti rice so I soaked the rice about an hour and cooked it 20 minutes. I added 1 teaspoon of grated fresh ginger and I clove of garlic. I used 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon and 4 cardamom pods. I used only 1 teaspoon cumin seed. I used low sodium chicken broth and did not add any salt. This recipe is a keeper and I will make it again and again.
This was the missing piece to the perfect Shwarmas that my husband used to buy in the middle east.
Very tasty and easy to follow directions. I will be making this again.
Itâ€™s just missing something. Itâ€™s certainly not what I was expecting, but okay.
Next time I'll add a little more of the spices on onion for a little stronger flavour. But other then that really enjoyed the texture of the rice compared to the rice cooker.
Followed others advice and used half the cumin and it was perfect. Everyone loved it including picky children.

I'm not usually a rice fan, but this was very tasty. I made it exactly the way the recipe was written and I will make it again. I am actually going to use the same spices on cauliflower rice, I think that would be really good. My husband who is a rice fan put this on at the top of his list to make again. Thanks
OMG! I love this! I go to an Indian restaurant and put this on my plate, but THIS recipe was SO much tastier than what I put on my plate in the restaurant! It was easy and quick to prepare.
Easy and excellent recipe to go with the Tikka Masala.
I followed the instructions to the letter and it was very tasty. It was a nice change to plain basmati rice which I make on a regular basis.

This is my absolute go-to every time Indian is on the menu for the evening. Itâ€™s perfect! Iâ€™ve never heard a complaint! The recipe also is a good base for southwestern-style cilantro lime rice. Simply omit all the spices, add some finely minced garlic to the onions and keep the status quo from there. When the rice is done, add 1/3-1/2 bunch chopped cilantro and the juice of 1 1/2 limes. Delicious.
I loved this rice. Trader Joe's has some nice dal in a can that you can eat with this rice. I probably only added 1/2 of the cumin that the recipe called for but that's my personal taste.
I cooked it and it is remarkably fabulous. Everyone loved it. I used chicken stock instead of water.
No change. It was delicious. Will make it a gain.

Didn't have whole cumin or cardamon seeds, so I used powdered. I could have used more, as it turned out, but the rice was wonderfully fragrant, even so. I would try it again, and increase the spices or get the whole seeds.
So good it tastes like itâ€™s from an Indian restaurant

So simple, easy, and good. Doubled the cardamom pods and cloves, halved the cumin seeds. Going to make this instead of plain rice whenever I serve Indian-style meals. (I sometimes use jarred simmer sauces for family weekday dinners, and this rice will enhance those meals quite a bit)..

This rice was really good! Excellent flavor, and pretty easy to put together :) I did substitute ground nutmeg in for the cardamom pods, but otherwise I think I followed the recipe pretty religiously. Served it under Chicken Tikka Masala, but did eat it by itself too, to make sure we liked it, and it was really good both ways. Family enjoyed it, will definitely make it again in the future.
AMAZING!!! Have made this twice now in one week and followed the recipe as written. The flavours were fabulous together. Definitely recommend this flavourful, fragrant rice!
Nice flavor. Made exactly as written. We enjoyed this!

I really liked this. I make rice way more than pasta or potatoes, so I'm always looking for new ideas on preparation. I used janatbellu's "translation" of whole to ground spices, otherwise I made it as written. The rice grains stayed separate and not gluey. But, I think it tastes even better the next day! 
I did add some veggies at the last few minutes: defrosted baby peas and white and gold corn, and bits of broccoli, and cooked some minced fresh carrots in with the rice. Served it with spicy, sauteed shrimp. Yum! Complete meal!

I used ground cumin and no the seeds as I didnt have any on hand. The flavour was good but the rice didnt come out as fluffy as I hopped. I will probably attempt to try this recipe again but soak it longer and add more oil so the rice does not stick to each other.

If you're like me, and mess up rice every time, then this is the recipe for you! I absolutely love it!!!!! However, I did make a few changes. First, I used Basmati Rice, instead of brown, and used 1/8 teaspoon of regular cumin, rather than the seeds. I also added a bay leaf in with the spices and used 2 cinnamon sticks instead of one. Lastly, after toasting the rice, I poured it into a rice cooker with about 3/4 a cup of water. Cooked for about 16 minutes, fluffed, and let it set for 5 more minutes. Without a doubt, this is best rice I've ever made!
I love Indian spices so I increased the amount of cardamom, clove and cumin. It's delicious.
It was good, but bland. I added lemon seasoning and cayenne pepper as well as melted fat from the lamb i was making for the main dish

This is a great basic recipe. I took the advice to reduce the cumin to a tea. I cooked the onions until they burnt a little which ads a nice touch. I used maybe less than a 1/4 t ground spices instead of the whole seeds of cardamom and clove. I don't know what soaking the rice did except definitely made it un-toastable. It instantly sticks to the pan. Very nice way to make rice extra special to serve with lentil soup or something else.
I love this recipe. I have made it several times. I have never been able to make rice that was this fluffy before. The KEY is to toast the spices and rice with the oil. It makes all the difference!

WOW as good as any Indian restaurant. So important to soak the rice. I also reduced the cumin, as others have said, and I also added a few cardamoms just because I love them. It came out perfectly and even my husband who is a chef said 'well done' but I'll praise the author of the recipe.

I made this to go along with my chicken tikka masala and was impressed with the results. I have made basmati based from the recipe found on the side of the rice package with less than stellar results. This recipe resulted in a side very similar to the rice at the restaurants. I did take the advise of several reviewers and cut down on the cumin to 1/2 teaspoon. I cut the onions razor thin and fried in ghee instead of oil (maybe too powerful of a butter flavor). Next time I will try veg oil to see the difference. Definitely a recipe that is going in my book. Thanks!
We skipped the cinnamon & it was fantastic. Never making plain white rice again!

This rice was delicious! 

i couldn't find the cardamom pods, and look forward to ordering some to try this recipe again.

With the cloves, cinnamon, and cumin as listed though, the flavors were delicious. 

Not a subtle flavor, but not overly powerful, and it balanced really well with a spicy chicken tikka masala.

Super flavorful rice and my house smells great too lol. However I did need to add a lot more salt than it originally called for. Also I've made this 3 times exactly to the recipe but the rice is always crunchy. I've had to tweak the proportions of liquid to rice to have a come outwits the perfect texture.

This is an amazing rice recipe that yielded probably the best rice I've ever had. I did make some tweaks to it to get it "just right": 1/4 tsp cumin instead of 1 tbsp; more cardamom pods (5) and whole cloves (4); 3 tbsp oil instead of 2; added 1/4 tsp saffron in 2 tbsp hot water -- saffron made a huge difference. Also cooked for 14 mins instead of 15 and let it sit covered for 10 mins after. All that said, this recipe gave me the baseline for an incredible plate of rice! Next time I might add more onion, because the golden onions were fantastic and I would like more of them in this dish. I plan to use this recipe often in the future.
Very easy to make and tasted great.

I was disappointed with this recipe. In the end it turned out ok because I added all sorts of other spices and flavors because I just found it lacking. The rice also got a little mushy, I think it's because I used jasmine rather than basmati rice.
This is a regular dish in our house. My boyfriend makes it so often that he has the recipe memorized. It lends itself well to doubling. The spices are just right and it is so yummy.
Very good recipe, I used a teaspoon of ground cumin.
I used one and half cups of chicken stock and one cup of water. It tasted great...
Very authentic tasting and easy to make!

After reading all of the previous reviews, I decided to change it up and use 1.5 heaping teaspoon of cumin seed, 3 cardamom seeds, and use the rice cooker after browning the rice. My rice cooker is a 3 cup cooker and I know that 1.5 cups of pre-soaked rice needs enough water to cover the rice by about a 1/4 inch. Came out a little too cinnamon for my taste. Maybe a half stick next time, otherwise very good. Surprisingly better the next day when the spices settled and weren't so sparky.

This is a great Indian rice recipe. It tastes like what my Indian neighbor makes. However, she adds fresh ginger to hers, so I did too. Maybe about one and a half or two teaspoons of minced fresh ginger.
Use less Cinnamon! 2" stick was way too much

I like this rice a lot but feel it needs double the spice. Also, feel like it is missing some moisture or creaminess so next time I make it I will try adding a bit of tomato paste, butter or oil at the end of the cooking time. This does go very well with the kafta kabobs, naan, minty raita, and some fresh onions as an Indian-style taco. Delicious!

I'm an Indian and I've eaten a lot of varieties of rice. Usually my mum cooks, but it was my first time cooking and I decided to make this recipe. I'm sorry to say but I've eaten much better things, and it simply didn't suit my taste. I'm sorry.. :(

Love this rice - I added saffron threads. Served to guests at a dinner party and everyone loved it, including my picky 4 year old. NEW UPDATE - Just made this in my Instant Pot Electric Pressure Cooker and it was great. I sautÃ©ed the onions in ghee while the rice soaked, then added ground spices. After I drained the rice I sautÃ©ed it along with the spices until lightly toasted and mixed with spices. I added a tsp saffron and then turned pressure cooker on for 3 minutes. After that I let the steam naturally release for 10 minutes before opening the vent. Fluffed with a fork and served. Perfectly cooked and delicious!
Very delicious. I gave it 4 stars only because I thought a tablespoon of cumin would be too much. I used 1 tsp. and it was perfect.

This rice turned out to be really delicious. I only made one small change, I used ghee in place of the oil. This turned out to be so good that even my pickiest eater loved it. I will definitely make this again, and again, and again.

Great, great recipe thank you. My son made it as is the first time- great rice. To the second batch of rice he made he added 1 1/2 tsp each of tumeric, cumin, & powered coriander. This recipe is definitely restaurant quality. Excellent.

Great aromatics, this rice was the best basmati rice I've ever made that tasted authentic. I did add about a tablespoon of Ghee (clarified butter) at the end at the recommendation of an Indian friend. It was delicious!

This was delicious! I made a few changes; substituted shallots for the onion, added a couple extra cardamom pods + cloves, and used about half the amount of cumin that the recipe calls for. I also substituted half of the water with some homemade stock that I had on hand. Loved it! Next time I'm going to try adding some saffron.

I made this for thanksgiving and boy did it smell nice! I must say beyond the scent, this is still plain rice that needs a sauce to go with it. Make sure to find a nice sauce (maybe with lamb) to accompany this rice!
Added saffron powder! Awesome recipe!
This is an amazing rice dish! I make it all the time for my family with an Indian meal. The best rice I have ever had!
This rice is delicious! It's become a family favorite with any Indian dish, as well as a side for roast chicken and fish.
I love this and very easy. Have to soak rice !!!
Amazing and easy luv it !
